channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Insists Tariffs Will Buoy the Economy and Ease Cost Concerns
item.description: The president rolled out a $12 billion bailout for farmers as he makes the case that his policy is working — or will soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The president announced $12 billion in bailout money for America’s farmers who have been battered in large part by his trade policies.

item.title: Trump Plans $12 Billion Bailout to Aid Farmers Hit by Tariffs
item.description: The federal aid comes after China boycotted American farm products in retaliation for U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Kevin Draper and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The money for farmers will come mostly from the Agriculture Department’s Farmer Bridge Assistance program.

item.title: Trump Clears Sale of More Powerful Nvidia A.I. Chips to China
item.description: Approval for the H200 chip followed months of haggling between tech industry backers and defense hawks.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration wants to encourage Chinese companies to use Nvidia’s H200 chip while limiting sales of the company’s newest chips, known as Blackwell.

item.title: A Frustrated Congress Pushes the Pentagon to Produce Its Boat Strike Orders
item.description: In a sign of bipartisan frustration with the Defense Department, the final defense policy bill aims to compel the Pentagon to share execute orders and video documentation.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth has posted edited footage of the strikes on social media, but has so far refused to share the full video with lawmakers.

item.title: Massachusetts Church Keeps Anti-ICE Nativity Scene, Defying Diocese Leaders
item.description: The Christmas display, which replaces Jesus, Mary and Joseph with a sign saying “ICE Was Here,” has drawn criticism from Catholic leaders and immigration officials.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: A Nativity scene at St. Susanna Parish in Dedham, Mass., displays a sign reading “ICE Was Here” in the spot where Jesus, Mary and Joseph would normally be.

item.title: Trump Criticizes Zelensky as Ukraine Peace Talks Drag On With European Leaders
item.description: Despite pressure from the Trump administration, Mr. Zelensky, after meeting with European leaders who vowed continued support in the war, said Ukraine’s position on territory had not changed.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Chris J Ratcliffe/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: From left: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany outside 10 Downing Street on Monday.

item.title: Russian Court Sentences 4 Soldiers to Prison for Killing Texan
item.description: Russell Bonner Bentley III, 64, who was living in the occupied Donbas region of Ukraine, was beaten and tortured to death after he was suspected of being an American saboteur, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman
item.media:description: Russell Bonner Bentley III visiting a memorial to victims of Nazi killings, in Donetsk, Ukraine, in 2017.

item.title: N.Y. Archdiocese Will Negotiate Sex-Abuse Settlement for 1,300 Accusers
item.description: The archdiocese will raise at least $300 million to fund the settlement. It has agreed with its accusers on a mediator to conduct negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Archdiocese said it had sold its Manhattan headquarters to raise money for a sex-abuse settlement.

item.title: With Cheap Tickets and Lax Etiquette, a Theater Builds an Older Fan Base
item.description: The Hollywood Classic cinema in Seoul is popular in a country where 70-year-olds now outnumber people in their 20s.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Woohae Cho
item.media:description: The ticket booth at the Hollywood Classic cinema in Seoul, the capital of South Korea, in November.

item.title: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Give Trump More Power to Fire Independent Officials
item.description: A ruling in the president’s favor in the case, which deals with his attempt to remove a member of the Federal Trade Commission, would be a major expansion of presidential authority.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monday’s case presented the first opportunity for the Supreme Court to issue a conclusive ruling on the underlying legal questions of President Trump’s firings.

item.title: Supreme Court Questions N.Y. Ban on Religious Exemptions for Vaccines
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court directed a lower court to review the ban, which applies to strict vaccine requirements in New York schools.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Up to 20 percent of students had religious exemptions from vaccines at some schools in Rockland County, N.Y., where there was a measles outbreak in 2019.

item.title: Honduras Issues Warrant for Juan Orlando Hernández
item.description: The attorney general said he had asked Interpol to detain Juan Orlando Hernández, who was freed from a U.S. prison last week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Andy Buchanan
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández was president of Honduras from 2014 to 2022 and was convicted on drug-trafficking charges in the United States last year.

item.title: Trump Stands in the Middle as Netflix and Paramount Vie for a Megadeal
item.description: The president has shattered norms by pledging to “be involved” in the regulatory fate of a transaction that could reshape the news and entertainment industries.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has often relished pitting rivals against each other, from his “Apprentice” TV boardroom to the West Wing.

item.title: Jared Kushner Is Part of Paramount’s Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Mr. Kushner’s private equity fund is one of the many groups helping Paramount mount a hostile bid to buy the group, whose holdings include CNN.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner founded his private equity firm, Affinity Partners, after President Trump’s first term and faced scrutiny over its deep reliance on the Saudi sovereign wealth fund.

item.title: G.O.P. Senators Push Health Care Options as Vote Looms
item.description: The Senate is set to vote later this week on a three-year extension of Affordable Care Act subsidies that Republicans oppose. The G.O.P. has yet to coalesce around an alternative.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Moreno, along with Senator Susan Collins, has proposed a measure to extend Affordable Care Act tax breaks for two years.

item.title: DeSantis Designates CAIR, Muslim Advocacy Group, a ‘Terrorist Organization’
item.description: The executive order from the Florida governor came after another Republican governor, Greg Abbott of Texas, issued a similar declaration last month.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s order comes after another Republican governor, Greg Abbott of Texas, issued a similar declaration against the Council on American-Islamic Relations.

item.title: How Japan Built a Rare-Earth Supply Chain Without China
item.description: The 15-year effort by Japan is a model for countries now scrambling to reduce their dependence on Beijing’s critical metals.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya

item.title: A.I. Videos Have Flooded Social Media. No One Was Ready.
item.description: Apps like OpenAI’s Sora are fooling millions of users into thinking A.I. videos are real, even when they include warning labels.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Why Some Doctors Say There Are Cancers That Shouldn’t Be Treated
item.description: Statistics show a clear spike in eight cancers in younger people, but that has brought a debate over whether many cases ever needed to be found.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Michael Macor/San Francisco Chronicle, via Getty Images
item.media:description: An image of a patient’s prostate. Patients in the early stages of prostate cancer and other types of cancer might safely wait to see if the disease progresses.

item.title: The Best New Restaurants in New York in 2025
item.description: Here are the new kids on the block our critics loved most this year.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan, Priya Krishna and Melissa Clark
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kabawa, where the chef Paul Carmichael presents his vision of Caribbean food.

item.title: Best New York City Dishes
item.description: Bánh cuốn, chicken bastilla and 10 other unforgettable plates from 2025.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: Nancy Mace: Why The Republican House Isn’t Working
item.description: The system in the House promotes control by party leaders over accountability and achievement.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Mace
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times

item.title: Top N.Y. Cannabis Official Resigns as Major Investigation Is Dropped
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul demanded the resignation of the head of New York’s Office of Cannabis Management following the withdrawal of a case against a Long Island-based company.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Omnium headquarters in Hauppauge, N.Y., earlier this year. It is unclear why a case against the company was withdrawn.

item.title: John Noble Wilford, Times Reporter Who Covered the Moon Landing, Dies at 92
item.description: He gave readers a comprehensive and lyrical account of the historic mission in 1969. His science coverage as a Pulitzer-winning journalist and an author took him around the world.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: John Noble Wilford in 1981. Recalling his coverage of the moon landing, he said, “I thought to myself, yes, this is the biggest story I will probably ever write in my career.”

item.title: University of Oklahoma Removes a Teacher It Says Urged Students to Protest
item.description: The protest was over the removal of another instructor, who gave a failing grade on a paper about gender that relied on the Bible as its main source.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Sue Ogrocki/Associated Press
item.media:description: The University of Oklahoma campus in Norman.
